flags.reasoning: The article dismisses ramp-based theories wholesale and declares with confidence that this new theory 'works,' but the mainstream archaeological consensus is that ramp-based theories remain the most credible, if incomplete, explanations. Multiple Egyptologists and engineers maintain that some form of ramp was almost certainly used. The new subtraction/trapezoid theory has not been peer-reviewed or subjected to archaeological scrutiny in any documented form found in the literature, so declaring it definitively as a working theory overstates its standing significantly.

flags.excerpt: The materials "left over" from reducing the trapezoid were then, in very efficient Egyptian fashion, used to produce the next pyramid on the plateau.
flags.reasoning: This claim — that leftover material from one pyramid was systematically used to build the next one on the Giza plateau — is presented as a probable fact without citation to any archaeological evidence, primary source, or expert. The three main Giza pyramids were built by different pharaohs over roughly a century and have distinct stone sources. This specific claim is speculative and not documented in Egyptological literature.
